review.title: Conservative, Proportional and Optimistic Contextual Discounting in the Belief Functions Theory
review.abstract: Information discounting plays an important role in the theory of belief functions and, generally, in information fusion. Nevertheless, neither classical uniform discounting nor contextual cannot model certain use cases, notably temporal discounting. In this article, new contextual discounting schemes, conservative, proportional and optimistic, are proposed. Some properties of these discounting operations are examined. Classical discounting is shown to be a special case of these schemes. Two motivating cases are discussed: modelling of source reliability and application to temporal discounting.

metadata.title: Conservative, Proportional and Optimistic Contextual Discounting in the Belief Functions Theory

sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that the solution to the problem is not a purely theoretical question, but a purely theoretical one.

sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: B. Classical discounting
sections.text: The most frequently used form of discounting in view of the discount factor α was proposed by Shafer in [2, pp. 251-255] and is later called classical discounting: α bel (A) = (1 − α) bel (A) т A (B (4)), which can be expressed as equivalent to mass functions as: α m (A) = (1 − α) m (A) х A (5) α m (E) = (1 − α) m (E) + α (6)

sections.heading: C. Contextual discounting
sections.text: Contextual discounting, an extension of classical discounting taking into account reliabilities that vary from class to class, was proposed by Mercier et. al. [6] and developed in [3], [4], [7]. This process uses vector α of discount factors attributed to elements of differentiating frames, i.e.: the contextual discounting of m of a bba m is equal to: a = m ² (7), b ² (8), c ², c ², c ², i 6 = j: 1, c = (9) The contextual discounting of m of a bba m is equal to: a = m ² (10) m ², c = m ². One of the inconveniences of this method is the fact that reliability factors are assigned to a discretion frame in which the reliability of cases in which the reliability of parts is distinguished is known.

sections.heading: D. Generalised contextual discounting
sections.text: The above-mentioned problem was dealt with in [4], [7], where generalized contextual discounting is proposed as a corrective mechanism. Here, too, the vector α of discount factors is used, but here they can also be defined for overlapping sets. The method uses canonical discounting of a subnormal discount factor [12] introduced by Denœux. The idea is to discount discount weights that differ from such a decomposition of bba m: α-N = A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A-A.

sections.heading: III. CONSERVATIVE, OPTIMISTIC AND PROPORTIONAL DISCOUNTING
sections.text: As a starting point for the conception of a discounting operation, a few hypotheses have been put forward: first, the information source S should excessively promote a number of solutions A, and therefore m (A) should be discounted by the factor αA, which corresponds to A. The behavior of the new discounting operation should resemble the behavior of the classical discounting, conflict mass m (∅) should be discounted, and new schemes should generalize the classical discounting factor. Furthermore, the determination of a non-zero discounting factor for fixed imbalances should entail the discounting of the mass attributed to the economy, while masses of sets that have no elements in common with the economy should remain unchanged. Such behavior is contrary to the contextual discounting proposed by Mercier et al. [6], which maintains the mass attributed to the economy, and other sets that we consider counterintuitively, especially in the case of many classes, but agree with the [3] suggested in the example.

sections.heading: A. Notation
sections.text: In the following sections, we will adhere to a notation similar to that in Section II. In order to distinguish the proposed discounting operations between them and avoid any confusion with existing systems, αc, а m will denote a conservative discounting of a bba m using the discounting vector α, which is defined for all elements of the discounting principle. If the group of classes for which discounting factors are defined is obvious or unimportant, the notation αc m will correspond to a discounting method. Finally, the analogous convention will be used for other types of discounting. Likewise, we will simplify notation by omitting the type of discounting (c for conservative, p for proportional, or o for optimistic) when an equation is valid for all types of discounting.

sections.heading: B. Conservative discounting
sections.text: As already mentioned, the assignment of m (A) by source S is exaggerated, and this mass should be discounted by αA. Let us now assume that some meta-knowledge additionally states that the stress on masses of supersets of A by source S depends to a large extent on class A. In view of the above statement, the mass attributed to AB should be discounted in the same way as m (A). Therefore, with conservative discounting, the empty set and all sets that have at least one element in common with source S are obtained by the same factor. In any case, a general consideration of this behavior results in: α c m (N) = m (N) · α ² (17) α ² m (A) = m (A) · maximum possible discounting (A).

sections.heading: C. Optimistic discounting
sections.text: Optimistic discounting is based on a hypothesis that differs from the conservative discounting hypothesis. This time, the meta-information on source S states that masses of supersets of A are affected independently of class A. These masses must not be discounted by αA. On the other hand, all subsets of A will be affected in the same way as A. This kind of discounting can be expressed for any type of superset of A by: α o m (∅) = m (∅) · 1 − (20) α o m (A) = m (A) · 1 - (A).

sections.heading: D. Proportional discounting
sections.text: The schemes proposed above represent two extremes of discounting strategies. Conservative means accepting the possibility that the mass of a superset (e.g. AB) fully corresponds to one of its components (e.g. A), which has otherwise been overestimated and should therefore be discounted. Conversely, if one assumes that the mass of a superset depends on a quantity that has not been overestimated (e.g. B), an optimistic discounting is used. Such behavior can be considered optimistic or bold, because any doubt as to whether a certain amount should be discounted or not implies a negative response. As the above schemes are the extreme cases, the need for an incidence between the solution seems natural. One way to do this without resorting to a mass-dependent calculation is to consider the discounting rate by some measure of dependence between a certain quantity and not implicit.

sections.heading: IV. PROPERTIES
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Generalisation of classical discounting
sections.text: The proposed discount systems generalize the classical discounting in the case of B = C. Such behavior stems simply from the fact that for each θ B all its subsets are discounted. Since all sets are subsets of B, all are affected in the same way (with the exception of B as expected).

sections.heading: B. Order invariance
sections.text: The result of the discounting operations across different classes is invariable in the order of these operations, for both conservative, optimistic and proportional discounting. The proof is omitted here because it is trivial and based on the commutative property of multiplication.

sections.heading: C. Operation grouping
sections.text: For all proposed schemes, the result of two discounting operations on sentences 1, 2 and discounting vectors α1, α2 successively corresponds to a single discounting operation on the combined discounting vector α = concatenation (α1, α2).α1, 1, 1, 2 m = α, 1, 2 m, if this property is easily generalizable for any number of discounting operations. sections.heading: V. EXAMPLES
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: B. Example 2: source reliability modelling
sections.text: Consider an example of a simplified detection problem from the air, borrowed from [13], [3]. The differentiation frame contains three classes: aircraft (a = ω1), helicopter (h = ω2) and rocket (r = ω3). Consider now that the sensor is over-reliable if the source is a helicopter or rocket with plausibility α2.3 = αh, r = 0.4, while it is reliable if the target is an airplane. Conservatively discounted bba αc m is: α c m ({a}) = 0.5 α c m ({r}) = 0.5 α m ({m}) = 0.5 α c m ({r}) = 0.3 α c m = a missile or rocket is interpreted as reliable.

sections.heading: VI. CASE STUDY: TEMPORAL DISCOUNTING
sections.text: The basic idea behind this discounting is that over time, information becomes partially obsolete, which can happen because the entity described by this particular information is dynamic, changes or is no longer observed. It is important to emphasize that different information becomes obsolete at possibly different speeds. This example motivates why the introduction of new contextual discounting schemes is necessary and why the existing one is insufficient. The first part shows some postulates about the time discounting itself. Next, the existing contextual discounting scheme is applied to the time discounting. Finally, the application of the proposed methods is demonstrated.

sections.heading: A. Postulates
sections.text: The postulates below imply that the temporal discounting should be subject to exponential decay, similar to the process of radioactive decay described by Ernest Rutherford at the beginning of the 19th century [14]. In fact, we opt for the solution in which the information "decays," i.e. a piece of information gradually becomes obsolete. In the following paragraphs, A denotes a quantity, A'E, about the reliability of which an additional piece of knowledge is available.t m (A) = m (A) · e (− λt) (38) λ = ln 2t1 / 2 (39) λ = lnNt1 / N (40) 1) half-life t1 / 2: The mass attributed to a piece of information is two times smaller than the initial mass after half-life t1 / 2. Thanks to this postulate, the persistence of various types of information can be compared by comparing their half-life.

sections.heading: B. Temporal discounting using contextual discounting

sections.heading: C. Temporal discounting using proposed discounting schemes
sections.text: In contrast to the contextual discounting, the proposed methods are meaningful enough to reflect the desired behavior of the temporal discounting. Let us use the same two cases mentioned in section VI-B6. Both methods have in common the calculation of the decay parameters λ and х. Furthermore, the discount rate vector values α correspond directly to the values of х as shown: α1 = [ω1 7 → 0.0025, ω2 7 → 0.5, ω3 7 → 0.8312] (66) α2 = [ω1 7 → 0.5743, ω2 7 → 0.5, ω3 7 → 0.8312] (67) Tables II and III show 3 different discounting methods for the two cases analyzed.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION AND PERSPECTIVES
sections.text: In this article, we have proposed and defined three types of contextual discounting: conservative, proportional and optimistic. These methods allow fine-grained modelling of the reliability of the sources. In addition, the techniques introduced can be applied to the temporal discounting, which has also been described. It has been shown that the existing contextual discounting introduced by Mercier [3] is not strong enough to model temporal discounting. In addition to the applications already outlined, the authors consider the use of temporal discounting in the context of intelligent transport perception. Different object classes seen from a vehicle should not be forgotten at the same tempo. For example, information on objects identified as buildings should be kept longer than static, but possibly mobile objects. Conversely, moving static objects would persist longer than moving objects. As a practical advantage, it can be mentioned that for a given discount rate vector, factors by which masses are multiplied can be pre-stored to obtain mass discounted and later use.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: This work was supported by the French Ministry of Defence DGA (Direction Générale de l'Armement) with a doctoral scholarship to Marek Kurdej.

referenceMentions.context: INTRODUCTION In many problems of information fusion, there is a need to allow for the reliability of a source [1].
While the first case is easily handled by classical discounting operation [2], the second one is more complex and existing solutions do not meet all possible use cases [3], [4].
While the first case is easily handled by classical discounting operation [2], the second one is more complex and existing solutions do not meet all possible use cases [3], [4].

In this article, we address this problem in the context of the theory of belief functions, also known as Dempster–Shafer theory [5], [2] by proposing three schemes for contextual discounting: conservative, proportional and optimistic.

metadata.abstractText: Information discounting plays an important role in the theory of belief functions and, generally, in information fusion. Nevertheless, neither classical uniform discounting nor contextual cannot model certain use cases, notably temporal discounting. In this article, new contextual discounting schemes, conservative, proportional and optimistic, are proposed. Some properties of these discounting operations are examined. Classical discounting is shown to be a special case of these schemes. Two motivating cases are discussed: modelling of source reliability and application to temporal discounting.
